qas.question: What purpose does the CJIS serve?
Where is the data for the NCIC located?

answers.text: Under the roof of the CJIS

qas.question: Do states have access to CJIS?

answers.text: Many state and local agencies use these data

plausible_answers.text: The Criminal Justice Information Services (CJIS) Division

qas.question: What opened in 1995 as the oldest agency division?
When did the CJIS division close?
What program is not under the roof of the CJIS?
What are state and local agencies not allowed to use for their own investigations?

plausible_answers.text: local, state, federal, and international law enforcement agencies

qas.question: What provides tools of sophisticated identification and information services to the FBI?

context: <b5_0>The Criminal Justice Information Services (CJIS) Division<b5_0/>, is located in <a0_0>Clarksburg, West Virginia<a0_0/>. Organized beginning in <a1_0><b6_0>1991<b6_0/><a1_0/>, the office opened in 1995 as the youngest agency division. The complex is the length of three football fields. It provides a <a2_0>main repository for information<a2_0/> in various data systems. <a3_0>Under the roof of the CJIS<a3_0/> are the programs for the <b7_0>National Crime Information Center<b7_0/> (NCIC), Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR), Fingerprint Identification, Integrated Automated Fingerprint Identification System (IAFIS), NCIC 2000, and the National Incident-Based Reporting System (NIBRS). <a4_0>Many state and local agencies use these <b8_0>data<a4_0/> systems<b8_0/> as a source for their own investigations and contribute to the database using secure communications. FBI provides these tools of sophisticated identification and information services to <b9_0>local, state, federal, and international law enforcement agencies<b9_0/>.
